Situation1: They oversee multiple teams, resolving conflicts and delays to ensure a critical project meets a strict deadline.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story:
I sit at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, phone buzzing with messages from team leads. As the architect in charge, I’m expected to keep this project on track—no excuses. The deadline looms, and every delay feels like a personal failure. My inbox pings again: another team needs my input to resolve a dispute. I rub my temples, glancing at the calendar. 

A sticky note reminds me: “Tax docs ready—file by next week.” I’ve always prided myself on being a responsible citizen, paying taxes early, following every guideline. This weekend, the community center is hosting a free vaccine clinic, and volunteers are needed. I want to help, to show up for my neighbors, especially after the year we’ve all had. But the project’s at a tipping point—if I step away, even for a few hours, we might miss the deadline. 

My mind races, torn between the demands of my profession and my duty to my community. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in, each expecting my full attention, each unwilling to wait.
